question_5.topic: Graph clustering and Minimum Spanning Tree (MST)

problem_description.edges: n(n-1)/2 edges, each weighted by pairwise distance
problem_description.goal: Partition n elements into k clusters to maximize the minimum distance between any pair of elements in different clusters

approach_1.name: Kruskal's with Early Stopping
steps: 1. Construct a complete graph with n vertices (one per element)
2. Create n(n-1)/2 edges, each weighted by dist(vi, vj)
3. Run Kruskal's algorithm: sort edges by weight (ascending) and add edges that don't create cycles
4. STOP when you have exactly k connected components (instead of continuing to 1 tree)
5. These k components are your k clusters
approach_1.time_complexity: O(n² log n) - sorting O(n²) edges takes O(n² log n²) = O(n² log n)

approach_2.name: Full MST + Remove Heaviest Edges
steps: 1. Construct a complete graph with n vertices and n(n-1)/2 edges weighted by distances
2. Compute the full MST using Kruskal's or Prim's algorithm (MST has n-1 edges)
3. Identify the k-1 heaviest edges in the MST
4. Remove these k-1 heaviest edges from the MST
5. This breaks the tree into k connected components (your k clusters)
approach_2.time_complexity: O(n² log n) - same as Approach 1
approach_2.note: Both approaches are equivalent and produce the same clustering

correctness_justification.key_insight: MST connects all points using edges with smallest weights, representing the 'closest connections' between regions of data
why_it_maximizes_min_distance: The MST greedily selects the smallest edges while keeping the graph connected
The heaviest edges in the MST represent the 'bottleneck connections' between different dense regions
Removing the k-1 heaviest edges cuts at the 'natural gaps' in the data
This ensures maximum separation between clusters while maintaining internal cluster cohesion
correctness_justification.proof_sketch: Suppose there exists a better clustering C' with larger minimum inter-cluster distance d'. Then the MST would need edges of weight ≥ d' to connect all points. But if we remove k-1 edges heavier than d' from the MST, we get ≥ k components, contradicting optimality. Therefore, removing the k-1 heaviest MST edges is optimal.

bottleneck_path_connection.definition: A bottleneck path between two vertices is a path that minimizes the weight of the LARGEST edge on the path (not the total path weight)

example.shortest_path_A_to_C: A->B->C with total weight 12, max edge weight 11
example.bottleneck_path_A_to_C: A->D->E->C with total weight 30, max edge weight 10
example.explanation: The bottleneck path has higher total weight but smaller maximum edge weight (10 < 11)

bottleneck_path_connection.mst_property: All paths in an MST are bottleneck paths (Week 6 Applied Problem 4, part b)
relevance_to_clustering: When we use MST for clustering, we ensure connections within each cluster use bottleneck paths
This means within-cluster paths avoid unnecessarily heavy edges
Removing the k-1 heaviest edges guarantees we cut at the true bottleneck connections between clusters
The minimum inter-cluster distance equals the weight of the (k-1)th heaviest edge in the MST

connection_to_week6_applied.problem_4: Bottleneck paths - proves that MST paths minimize maximum edge weight, validating why MST gives optimal clustering structure
connection_to_week6_applied.problem_5: Reverse Kruskal's algorithm - removes edges from heaviest to lightest while maintaining connectivity, directly parallels the clustering approach of removing k-1 heaviest edges

solution_summary.approach_1: Run Kruskal's algorithm with early stopping when there are k connected components (k clusters).
solution_summary.approach_2: Compute full MST via Prim's or Kruskal's, then remove k-1 heaviest edges to form k clusters.
